data.subtitle: Huitzilopochtli- "Hummingbird of the South" / "Left-Handed Hummingbird"
data.name: Aztec - Huitzilopochtli

listDisplay.primary: Aztec - Huitzilopochtli - Huitzilopochtli- "Hummingbird of the South" / "Left-Handed Hummingbird"
listDisplay.expandedContent:
The patron god of the Mexica people, Huitzilopochtli was the solar deity of war and sacrifice who guided his
                people from their legendary homeland of Aztlan to found the great city of Tenochtitlan. His daily battle
                against darkness required the nourishment of human hearts and blood, making him the driving force behind
                Aztec expansionism and ritual sacrifice.

periods.description: Huitzilopochtli guided the Mexica from their legendary homeland through divine mandate
His sign (eagle on cactus) indicated location for city founding on Lake Texcoco
Became state cult deity, central to imperial ideology and military expansion

tonalpohualli.description: Birth day of Huitzilopochtli in Aztec calendar
Major festival of Huitzilopochtli with human sacrifice

primary.findings: Sacrificial stones, warrior remains, ceramic vessels with god's likeness

primary.purpose: Nourish the sun god for daily journey across sky
Ensure solar rebirth and military strength

sacrificialRites.significance: Cosmic necessity - sun required chalchiuhatl (precious water = blood) to continue its path

militaryAssociations.title: Divine patron of Mexica state
militaryAssociations.role: Justified imperial warfare as cosmic necessity
militaryAssociations.symbolism: Eagle symbolism connected to military orders (Cuauhtin - Eagles)
militaryAssociations.expansionism: Aztec expansion (1428-1521) linked to fulfilling Huitzilopochtli's mandate

culturalTransmission.preColumbian: Likely evolved from earlier Toltec solar cults with Nahua traditions
culturalTransmission.colonialAdaptation: Spanish friars documented extensively but condemned practices as demonic
culturalTransmission.modernNahua: Contemporary Nahua communities maintain modified veneration in syncretized practices

data.description:
The most powerful and feared god of the Aztec pantheon, Tezcatlipoca was the supreme deity, lord of night,
                sorcery, and destiny. His obsidian mirror revealed all secrets and controlled fate. As "He Who Is at the
                Shoulder," he was the invisible, omnipresent force testing humanity through temptation and adversity.

data.subtitle: Quetzalcoatl- "Feathered Serpent" / "Precious Twin"
data.description:
The Feathered Serpent is one of the most important deities of ancient Mesoamerica. As god of wind, learning, and creation,
                Quetzalcoatl brought civilization to humanity - the calendar, writing, agriculture, and the arts. He represents the
                union of earth (serpent) and sky (quetzal bird), the boundary between the material and spiritual realms.

sections.content:

                union of earth (serpent) and sky (quetzal bird), the boundary between the material and spiritual realms.

sections.title: Description
sections.content:
Among the oldest and most revered deities of Mesoamerica, Tlaloc was the god of rain, fertility, and water.
                Predating the Aztecs by millennia, his goggle-eyed visage appears in the ruins of Teotihuacan. He brought
                the life-giving rains that made agriculture possible, but also the devastating floods, hail, and lightning
                that could destroy crops and lives. His paradise, Tlalocan, awaited those who died by water or lightning.

listDisplay.primary: Aztec - Coatlicue - Coatlicue- "Serpent Skirt" / "She of the Serpent Skirt"
listDisplay.secondary:
The primordial earth mother goddess, Coatlicue embodies the duality at the heart of Aztec religion.
...
listDisplay.expandedContent:
The primordial earth mother goddess, Coatlicue embodies the duality at the heart of Aztec religion.
                Her terrifying appearance - a skirt of writhing serpents, a necklace of human hearts and hands,
                clawed feet, and two serpent heads - represents both the life-giving earth that nurtures crops and
                the devouring grave that reclaims all living things. She is creation and destruction inseparable.

data.name: Aztec - Coatlicue

sections.title: Description
sections.content:
The primordial earth mother goddess, Coatlicue embodies the duality at the heart of Aztec religion.
                Her terrifying appearance - a skirt of writhing serpents, a necklace of human hearts and hands,
                clawed feet, and two serpent heads - represents both the life-giving earth that nurtures crops and
                the devouring grave that reclaims all living things. She is creation and destruction inseparable.

listDisplay.secondary: The supreme creator god of the Maya pantheon, Itzamna is the lord of the heavens, inventor of writin...
listDisplay.expandedContent:
The supreme creator god of the Maya pantheon, Itzamna is the lord of the heavens, inventor of writing
                and the calendar, master of medicine and learning. Depicted as a wise, aged man or as a great cosmic
                caiman, he dwells in the highest of the thirteen heavens and is the father of countless gods. With
                his consort Ixchel, he presides over creation, knowledge, and the healing arts that sustain humanity.

data.summary:
The supreme creator god of the Maya pantheon, Itzamna is the lord of the heavens, inventor of writing
                and the calendar, master of medicine and learning. Depicted as a wise, aged man or as a great cosmic
                caiman, he dwells in the highest of the thirteen heavens and is the father of countless gods. With
                his consort Ixchel, he presides over creation, knowledge, and the healing arts that sustain humanity.

data.name: Maya - Chaac

sections.content:
Among the oldest and most widely worshipped deities of the Maya, Chaac is the god of rain, thunder,
                and lightning. With his distinctive long nose and jade ornaments, he wields a great lightning axe
                to split the clouds and release the waters that sustain all life. As the lord of agriculture and
                fertility, Chaac was essential to Maya survival, his favor bringing bountiful harvests and his
                anger devastating droughts. His goggle-eyed visage adorns countless temples across the Maya world.

data.name: Maya - Ixchel

hoverInfo.quick:
The great Moon Goddess of the Maya, Ixchel embodies the creative and destructive powers of feminine
...

gridDisplay.subtitle: Ix Chel- "Lady Rainbow" / "She of the Rainbow"
gridDisplay.title: Maya - Ixchel

data.subtitle: Ix Chel- "Lady Rainbow" / "She of the Rainbow"

listDisplay.expandedContent:
The great Moon Goddess of the Maya, Ixchel embodies the creative and destructive powers of feminine
                divinity. As goddess of the moon, childbirth, medicine, and weaving, she presides over the cycles
                of life, fertility, and death. Appearing both as a beautiful young woman and as a fearsome crone,
                she represents the transformative power of the feminine across all stages of life. Her sacred shrine
                on the island of Cozumel drew pilgrims from across the Maya world for centuries.

The great Moon Goddess of the Maya, Ixchel embodies the creative and destructive powers of feminine

data.subtitle: Ah Pukuh- "The Destroyer" / "The Fleshless One"

sections.title: Description
sections.content: The terrifying god of death, decay, and the underworld, Ah Puch rules over Xibalba, the Maya realm of the dead. Depicted as a skeletal figure with protruding ribs, exposed spine, and a bloated belly of corruption, he embodies the horror and inevitability of death. Yet the Maya understood death not as an end but as a transformation - and Ah Puch, however fearsome, was part of the cosmic cycle that made rebirth possible. His defeat by the Hero Twins established the pattern of death and resurrection at the heart of Maya religion.

Yet the Maya understood death not as an end but as a transformation - and Ah Puch, however fearsome, was part of the cosmic cycle that made rebirth possible. His defeat by the Hero Twins established the pattern of death and resurrection at the heart of Maya religion.

data.description:
The great feathered serpent is one of the most important deities of Mesoamerica, worshipped from the
                earliest Olmec civilizations through the Maya and Aztec empires. As K'uk'ulkan among the Yucatec Maya
                and Q'uq'umatz among the K'iche', this winged serpent god brought knowledge, civilization, and the
                sacred calendar to humanity. His descent as a serpent of light at Chichen Itza each equinox remains
                one of the world's most spectacular archaeoastronomical phenomena.
